subject: Re: [junit] Parameterized Test Case example
msgSnippet: ... I spot two things duplicated, both being methods calls: assertCorrectAge() and DateUtil.makeDate().  Both of those are trivial to change in one fell swoop.
messageBody:
On Nov 20, 2003, at 4:52 PM, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> Mike Clark wrote:
>>
>> To my mind, this approach is more explicit than the parameterized test
>> case example. That is, I prefer the level of test language used here
>> over the language used to coerce JUnit to do it for me. But that's
>> just my mind...
>
> Agreed: it's easier to understand, but more tests mean more code. I
> wanted to be able to write tests with data. Why duplicate all that
> stuff?!
>

I spot two things duplicated, both being methods calls:
assertCorrectAge() and DateUtil.makeDate(). Both of those are trivial
to change in one fell swoop.


> I don't think overriding runTest() and creating a TestSuite "by hand"
> is
> so advanced: it's how JUnit worked before they added the
> reflection-based stuff, anyway.

I didn't claim those constructs were advanced. Rather, I noted that
not using those constructs yielded a more explicit set of tests, to me.
And I was curious why you chose those constructs over individual test
case methods, which I think is the obvious solution. Thanks for
expounding on that.

Mike
